answers.author: Matthew Reges
answers.text:
Can the websites where you've posted provide hit counts or further info on page views? The analytics there are helpful to learn whether you're not getting exposure or whether something in the posting is unappealing to candidates. If my hit counter showed a 10:1 ratio of hits to applicants, I was happy, but 100:1 was a red flag.
Your position profile pdf looks fine to me.
Municipal leagues? In NM as well as Texas. Virginia's municipal league frequently posts jobs on behalf of neighboring states.
Were the university postings only MPA-oriented? If so, broadening to well-ranked MBA schools might help: maybe BYU, Arizona, ASU, UT Austin, Baylor, Rice, UCLA, UC Irvine.
Good luck!

answers.author: Robert Carty
answers.text:
Good advice. You might also consider including the ad in ICMA's non-member newsletter, which will increase exposure beyond membership by about 35,000 readers. I also emailed some ideas directly regarding ad copy that could help. I've run the data on hits, and it looks like you're hitting Matt's recommended rate of ~10:1. You just need more hits! Our ads are also cycled to indeed.com, so it's surprising you're not getting more exposure from that resource.

answers.author: John Zakian
answers.text:
LinkedIn...  all the suggestions plus where you have already advertised are solid but the one source which continues to significantly exponentially grow is LinkedIn... also, the overall professional job market is getting hot and something to consider is that it is not where you've posted that is holding back responses but, rather, it could be the salary range.

author: Jared Cobb
text: We've been recruiting for a finance director for over a month now and only have two applicants. The position has been posted with ICMA, local newspapers, university job boards, and the city website. We also recently posted the position with GFOA. Other than hiring an executive recruiting firm, what other resources are available? Thanks in advance for your help!
title: Recruiting
